title: If 2x^2+xy-3y^2+x+ay-10= (2x+3y+b) (x-y-2),then a+b is equal to? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well since the LHS has been expressed as the product of two factors we can say that  [math]x-y-2  [/math]  is a factor of the expression in LHS We can express the LHS in the following form. [math]2x^2+xy-3y^2+x+ay-10=(x-y-2)(2x+3y+5)+(a+11)y[/math] Here  [math](2x+3y+5)[/math] is the quotient on dividing by (x-y-2) and (a+11)y is the remainder. Now since (x-y-2) is a factor ,the remainder must be 0. [math]a+11=0  [/math] So [math]a=-11[/math] Comparing with the RHS we get b=5 So [math]a+b=-11+5=-6[/math]

With just 1 equation as such,[math] 2x^2 +xy -3y^2 + x + ay - 10 = (2x^2 -2xy -4x +3xy -3y^2 -6y+b(x-y-2) [/math] =>[math] xy + x + ay -10 = xy -4x -6y +b(x-y-2)[/math] => [math] 3x +6y - 10 -bx +2b = -y(a+b)[/math] => [math]a+ b = (3(x+2y) -10 - b(x+2))/(-y)[/math] =>[math] a + b = (b(x + 2) + 10 - 3(x+ 2y))/y [/math]This is as far as i can go, please correct me if I am wrong
